channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Announces Offensive in Kherson, as Inspectors Head to Nuclear Plant
item.description: The scale of Ukraine’s push in the Kherson region was unclear, but it has vowed for months to mount a counteroffensive to retake territory seized by Russia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers of Ukraine’s Territorial Defense Forces at a frontline position near Bakhmut, in the eastern Donetsk region, on Monday.

item.title: More Vital Than Ever, Ukraine’s Trains Bind a Land Fractured by War
item.description: With the skies and ports closed, Ukraine’s railroads have been crucial to efforts to flee, to return, to keep the country going or to simply reclaim some semblance of normal life.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Lynsey Addario
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Passengers rushed to board an 18-hour express train from Kyiv to Warsaw early this month.

item.title: Iraq Clashes Leave 12 Dead After Muqtada al-Sadr Says He’s Leaving Politics
item.description: The violence erupted after the powerful Shiite cleric Muqtada al-Sadr said he is leaving politics. Protesters supporting Mr. Sadr took to the streets of the capital, Baghdad, and security forces opened fire.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:description: Supporters of Mr. Sadr and the police in Baghdad’s Green Zone on Monday. Security forces closed roads south of the capital to prevent more protesters from arriving.

item.title: As Rome Burns (or at Least Its Garbage), a Mayor Dares to Dream
item.description: Could a solution to Rome’s perpetual trash crisis really be in sight? Mayor Roberto Gualtieri would like to think so.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Alessandro Penso for The New York Times
item.media:description: A worker at a junkyard in Rome searched for his dog, which had been missing since the lot caught fire last month, one of a rash of such blazes across the city.

item.title: Ukraine Announces Push in South; U.N. Inspectors Head to Nuclear Site
item.description: The Ukrainian military said it had launched offensive operations in multiple areas in the Kherson region. U.N. experts could soon visit the Russia-controlled Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant, where shelling has sparked fears of calamity.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A badly damaged apartment building on Sunday in the city of Slovyansk in the Kramatorsk District of the Donetsk region.

item.title: The First Shipment of Iranian Military Drones Arrives in Russia
item.description: Russia could deploy the drones in its war against Ukraine to conduct air-to-surface attacks, carry out electronic warfare and identify targets, according to U.S. officials.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: In this photo released by the Iranian Army on Thursday, a drone is launched as part of a military drill in Iran.

item.title: In Brazil, the Last Member of an Isolated Indigenous Tribe Dies
item.description: Known as the “Man of the Hole,” the last member of an Indigenous group was found dead this month, marking the first recorded disappearance of an isolated tribe in the country.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance and André Spigariol
item.media:description: A still image from a video provided by the Brazilian government showing one of the huts built by the “Man of the Hole” in Rondônia State in 2018.

item.title: Angola’s Ruling Party, MPLA, Retains Power in Tightest Election Yet
item.description: The Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola won in the general election with the lowest margin since coming to power in 1975.
item.dc:creator: Gilberto Neto and Lynsey Chutel
item.category: Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola
National Union for the Total Independence of Angola
item.media:description: President João Lourenço of Angola celebrated his election victory at his party’s headquarters in Luanda, Angola, on Monday.

item.title: Vancouver Moves to Sue Big Oil After Deadly Fires and Disastrous Floods
item.description: A potential lawsuit by Vancouver would be the first in Canada to target the fossil fuel industry’s role in climate change.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Melissa Renwick for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scars left by a wildfire that destroyed the small town of Lytton, British Columbia.

item.title: Air France Under Scrutiny Over Safety Incidents
item.description: Two pilots have recently been suspended after a cockpit fight, bringing to light new concerns over poorly observed safety protocols at the French airline.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: News of the altercation between two pilots while they were airborne has brought to light broader safety issues at Air France.

item.title: China Charges 28 People, Months After Brutal Beating of Women
item.description: The attack at a restaurant, captured on video, prompted outraged discussion about misogyny. The government sought to change the topic to gangs.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Zixu Wang
item.media:description: A still image taken from a video showing two women on the ground after being assaulted by a group of men in Tangshan, China, in June. On Monday the authorities announced that charges had been filed in the case as part of a broader investigation of gang activity in the city.

item.title: Xi Jinping’s Vision for Tech Self-Reliance in China Runs Into Reality
item.description: After heavy national investment in semiconductors to break a dependence on global chips, Mr. Xi seems unhappy with the results.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan

item.title: Cloud Wars: Mideast Rivalries Rise Along a New Front
item.description: As climate change makes the region hotter and drier, the U.A.E. is leading the effort to squeeze more rain out of the clouds, and other countries are rushing to keep up.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin and Bryan Denton

item.title: Over Caves and Over Budget, Mexico’s Train Project Barrels Toward Disaster
item.description: Pitched as a way to develop the country’s poorest region, the Maya Train is threatened by a ballooning budget and rushed construction over fragile terrain. But Mexico’s president has refused to slow it down.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Alejandro Cegarra
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: A landslide at a construction site for the Mayan Train, before the route was changed to travel through the jungle, in Playa del Carmen, Mexico.

item.title: Deadly Floods Devastate an Already Fragile Pakistan
item.description: More than 1,100 have died as record monsoon rains inundate the country, washing away bridges, roads and crop fields. Much of Pakistan is underwater.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak, Raymond Zhong and Ihsanullah Tipu Mehsud
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Army troops evacuated people from a flood-hit area in Rajanpur, Punjab district, Pakistan, on Saturday.

item.title: Greenland’s Melting Ice Sheet Could Raise Sea Levels by Nearly a Foot: Study
item.description: The study reached a more drastic conclusion than earlier assessments in part because it used a different method to gauge ice loss.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:description: An iceberg in Baffin Bay near Pituffik, Greenland, in July.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: China Charges 28 People in Beating of Women
item.description: Plus the controversy over seabed mining and the geopolitical drama surrounding Taiwan’s microchips
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: A still image taken from a video showing two women on the ground after being assaulted by a group of men in Tangshan, China, in June. On Monday the authorities announced that charges had been filed in the case as part of a broader investigation of gang activity in the city.

item.title: Be ‘Less Squeamish’ About Drinking Recycled Wastewater, British Official Says
item.description: As droughts become more frequent, drinking water that has been reprocessed from sewage treatment is the future, the head of Britain’s Environment Agency said.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: A sewage treatment plant in Rickmansworth, England. Toilet-to-tap recycling is “perfectly safe and healthy, but not something many people fancy,” the head of Britain’s Environment Agency wrote this week.

item.title: Did My Cat Just Hit On Me? An Adventure in Pet Translation
item.description: Entrepreneurs are aiming to put A.I.-powered pet translation tools into our pockets.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Americans Who Stutter
item.description: President Biden’s approach to his own stutter highlights the stigma that the condition still brings.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: In ‘Little Venice,’ Cruise Ships and an Influx of Tourists
item.description: With a ban on large cruise ships in the waters surrounding Venice, nearby Chioggia is one of the new go-to ports. While many welcome the new visitors, some worry that the tourism boom could turn sour.
item.dc:creator: Anna Momigliano
item.media:credit: Susan Wright for The New York Times
item.media:description: The cruise ship Viking Sea in Chioggia’s port. Following a series of protests from environmental groups last year, the Italian government recently started enforcing a ban on large cruise ships from the portion of the lagoon surrounding Venice’s historic center. Chioggia is now one of the alternative ports.

item.title: Secret Data, Tiny Islands and a Quest for Treasure on the Ocean Floor
item.description: Mining in parts of the Pacific Ocean was meant to benefit poor countries, but an international agency gave a Canadian company access to prized seabed sites with metals crucial to the green energy revolution.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times

item.title: In Algeria, Macron Seeks to Reshape Traumatic Ties With France
item.description: On a three-day visit, the French president said he was seeking “truth and acknowledgment” over the war and colonialism.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France visiting Saint Eugene Cemetery in Algiers, Algeria, on Friday.

item.title: U.N. Experts to Visit Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant in Ukraine
item.description: Both Russia and Ukraine welcomed the news, even as they repeated accusations that the other side was responsible for shelling the area around the plant.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky, Austin Ramzy, Andrew E. Kramer and Shashank Bengali
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: More attacks near a Ukrainian nuclear plant.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Record Heat Disrupts China
item.description: Plus Pakistan is hit by deadly floods and Australia weighs Indigenous recognition
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser
item.media:description: People walked across a dried-up section of Poyang Lake that is facing low water levels due to a regional drought in Lushan, Jiangxi province, China, last week.

item.title: Shelling Near Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant in Ukraine Heightens Concern
item.description: Neither Russia nor Ukraine appeared to be pausing attacks in the south, even as talks continued over allowing international inspectors to visit the Zaporizhzhia power plant.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olena Bondarchyk, 46, and others fleeing Enerhodar, Ukraine, and other Russian-occupied territories wait at a Ukrainian controlled checkpoint as shelling continues around the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant.

item.title: At Least 32 Are Killed in Clashes Between Rival Militias in Libya Kill
item.description: The worst fighting in two years rocked Tripoli on Saturday, as residents feared a return to war.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Fighters loyal to the current prime minister rolled through a street in the Libyan capital, Tripoli, on Saturday after clashes between rival militias.

item.title: Danish School Is Engulfed by Bullying and Sex Abuse Scandal
item.description: Crown Prince Frederik of Denmark and his wife, Princess Mary, pulled their son from the institution, saying that they were “deeply shaken by the reports.”
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Jasmina Nielsen
item.media:description: Herlufsholm, a boarding school, received intense backlash after a documentary on Denmark’s TV2 exposed accusations of sex abuse, bullying and violence.

item.title: Ron DeSantis’s Florida
item.description: How the Republican governor is turning the swing state into a right-wing laboratory.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis.

item.title: Referendum Seeks to Mend the Open Wound at Australia’s Heart
item.description: The new prime minister is seeking support for an Aboriginal Voice to Parliament, even enlisting the backing of Shaquille O’Neal. Here’s what it would entail, and why it faces an uncertain path.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: A traditional Indigenous smoking ceremony opened this session of Australia’s Parliament in Canberra last month.

item.title: U.S. Warships Sail Taiwan Strait, Defying Chinese Pressure
item.description: Two guided-missile cruisers were the first to visit since China began extensive military drills after Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The guided-missile cruiser Antietam in the Taiwan Strait on Sunday, in a photo released by the U.S. Navy. China said that its own forces “remain on high alert.”

item.title: Pakistan Hit by Deadly Floods of ‘Epic Proportions’
item.description: More than 1,000 have died since mid-June from flooding that a senior official called a “climate-induced humanitarian disaster.”
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Shahid Saeed Mirza/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rescuing people in Rajanpur District of Punjab Province, Pakistan, on Saturday.

item.title: Lessons Learned, Israel’s Unlikely Islamist Kingmaker Looks Ahead
item.description: Mansour Abbas, the first Arab politician to lead his party into an Israeli governing coalition, says the yearlong experiment was just a beginning.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mansour Abbas last year in Umm Al-Fahm, Israel. He is the leader of a small Islamist party called Raam that made history last year by becoming the first independent Arab party to enter an Israeli governing coalition.

item.title: With Disaster Looming, Inspectors Set to Visit Ukraine Nuclear Plant
item.description: While Ukrainian officials began handing out iodine pills for radiation, the United Nations nuclear watchdog neared a plan to send a team of experts as early as next week.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Katrin Bennhold and Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shelling around the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant, on the banks of the Dnipro River, has raised fears of a catastrophic nuclear accident.

item.title: Western officials criticize Russia for blocking a joint U.N. document on nuclear disarmament.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Matt Surman
item.media:description: The United Nations conference on nuclear nonproliferation, in which Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken spoke, ended this month without the adoption of a joint document by participating nations.

item.title: Serbia’s Leader Cancels EuroPride. Organizers Say They Will Go Ahead Anyway.
item.description: The annual gay pride event was to take place in September in Belgrade. President Aleksandar Vucic said the timing was bad, citing “numerous problems” currently affecting the country.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A Pride parade in June in Vienna. Organizers said that the EuroPride event in Belgrade would be a milestone for the L.G.B.T.Q.I. community in Serbia.

item.title: The Long Road Ahead for Colonial Reparations
item.description: Former colonies have felt increasingly empowered to demand compensation from European powers. But even the successful efforts look like exceptions so far.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Citadelle, one of 30 forts ordered up by Jean-Jacques Dessalines, Haiti’s first ruler, in preparation for what he called “an eventual offensive return of the French.”

item.title: A Holy British Island, Where the Reckless Try to Outrace the Tide
item.description: As the cradle of Christianity in northern England, the isle of Lindisfarne attracts 650,000 visitors a year, some of whom ignore the warning signs of when it’s safe to cross a causeway that twice a day is submerged.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Andrew Testa
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: High tide beginning to cover the causeway to Holy Island.

item.title: The 5 Love Languages at 30
item.description: Why have they endured as a self-help phenomenon?
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: At One of Canada’s Top Destinations, Tourists Are Back but Much Has Changed
item.description: The towns in and around Banff National Park are teeming again, but overseas visitors are scarce, as are hotel and restaurant workers.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Most of the tourists flocking to Banff National Park this summer are Canadians.

item.title: Sanna Marin’s Party Scandal Highlights Finland’s Generational Divides
item.description: Leaked videos featuring Sanna Marin dancing have raised the question of whether she is held to a different standard than older, male leaders are.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sanna Marin of Finland.

item.title: ‘The Best Tool We Have’ for Self-Harming and Suicidal Teens
item.description: Studies indicate that dialectical behavior therapy offers greater benefits than more generalized therapy. But treatment is intensive, and expensive.
item.dc:creator: Matt Richtel
item.media:credit: Anastasiia Sapon for The New York Times
item.media:description: “There’s no medication for suicidal behavior,” said Michele Berk, a psychologist at Stanford University. “The patient needs to learn other behavioral skills that the medication does not teach you.”

item.title: War Brings Ukraine’s Women New Roles and New Dangers
item.description: Women have become an all-important force in the fight. But even as they mobilize, they are increasingly bearing the worst of the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Emile Ducke
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of Chernihiv, Ukraine, listening to Hanna discuss the risks of land mines. She is among a growing number of Ukrainian women who have been trained in demining, a job they were unable to have until recently.

item.title: Ukraine Weighs a Risky Offensive to Break Out of a Stalemate
item.description: Both Russia and Ukraine are preparing for a protracted standoff, but Ukraine has greater incentive to try to avoid it.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Anton Troianovski and Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian heavy artillery crew after going for a swim in a lake near Chasiv Yar, in the Donbas region in Ukraine on Thursday.

item.title: This Is Not the Monkeypox That Doctors Thought They Knew
item.description: The patients turning up at clinics often have a range of symptoms that are not typical of the infection. Some of the infected seem to have no symptoms at all.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: KC Nwakalor for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Dimie Ogoina, author of a study of monkeypox cases in Nigeria that documented unusual new symptoms. “If what is happening in Europe and the global North had not happened, I don’t think that paper would be discussed,” he said.

item.title: Here Are the Challenges Ahead for California’s Ban on Gas Cars
item.description: Enforcement could be complex and legal challenges are likely. But ultimately, experts say, success or failure will depend on steady supply and buyers’ appetite.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times
item.media:description: California’s policy will reverberate across the nation.

item.title: Ethiopian Airstrike Hits Kindergarten as Fighting Spreads in Tigray
item.description: Local medics said seven people died, including several children, as the region in northern Ethiopia plunged deeper into conflict just days after a truce collapsed.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: A still image taken from a video, showing destruction at a playground in Mekelle, the capital of Ethiopia’s Tigray region, on Friday.

item.title: Latvia tears down a controversial Soviet-era monument in its capital.
item.description: A 260-foot-tall obelisk erected in 1985 to honor Soviet soldiers who ended the country’s World War II Nazi occupation was toppled on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai

item.title: Fighting Between U.S. and Iran-Backed Militias Escalates in Syria
item.description: Two strikes on U.S. military sites have been tied to forces aligned with Iran, raising tensions just as Washington appears close to striking a new nuclear deal with Tehran.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi, Raja Abdulrahim and Adam Entous
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: American forces patrolling in Syria’s northeastern Hasakeh Province in May.

item.title: E.P.A. to Designate PFAS, or ‘Forever Chemicals,’ as Hazardous
item.description: A proposed rule would require companies to report spills of two toxic chemicals that have been linked to cancer.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: PFAS chemicals have been found in a range of products including carpets, waterproof clothing and food packaging, including some microwave popcorn bags.

item.title: Zelensky Is Under Pressure to Launch a Counteroffensive
item.description: Both sides are preparing for a protracted war, but Ukraine has an incentive to counterattack this fall, before the rainy season.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers on both sides of the war have spent the last few weeks dug in trenches, weathering artillery bombardments and without any signs of meaningful advance.

item.title: Conspiracy Theories
item.description: How more funding for the I.R.S. became a political firestorm.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times

item.title: The Dugong ‘Sea Cow’ Has Vanished from China’s Waters, Study Says
item.description: The study said the dugong, a vegetarian mammal that ranges across Asia and Africa, has essentially vanished from the country’s coastline.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A dugong in the lagoons of New Caledonia, east of Australia. The species has become the first large vertebrate to go “functionally extinct” in China’s coastal waters.

item.title: Ukraine Pokes the Russian Bear With Attacks and Mockery
item.description: Driven by deep anger at Russia and the need to rally support at home and abroad, Ukraine is regularly goading its much more powerful antagonist.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians wrapped themselves in the country’s flags at Maidan Square during the parade of captured Russian tanks as they celebrated Independence Day in Kyiv on Wednesday.

item.title: ‌A Social Media Star of a Changed Middle East: An Arab From Israel in Dubai
item.description: Nuseir Yassin, a Palestinian citizen of Israel with nearly 60 million followers, has taken advantage of new diplomatic ties to move to the United Arab Emirates — angering many Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Andrea DiCenzo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nuseir Yassin, a Palestinian born and raised in Israel, was one of the first Israeli passport holders to take advantage of new diplomatic relations between Israel and the United Arab Emirates.

item.title: How to Plan a Sustainable Trip
item.description: Organizing a responsible visit to sensitive areas like the Galápagos Islands or Antarctica involves research, decoding certifications and possibly a travel adviser.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac

item.title: Review: “The Arc of a Covenant,” by Walter Russell Mead
item.description: In “The Arc of a Covenant,” Walter Russell Mead makes the case that U.S. support for the Jewish state has benefited America more than critics allow.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tepperman
item.media:description: Activists in Jerusalem, October 2020.

item.title: The Long Tail of Covid-19 Disinformation
item.description: Almost all of Australia and New Zealand’s pandemic restrictions have been lifted. Yet the protests continue.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A protest last November in Sydney, Australia, against vaccine mandates and Covid lockdowns.
